awd_titl_txt: NRT-IGE: PhD Career Ladder Program: A grassroots approach to career development
awd_abstract_narration:
Stony Brook University's PhD Career Ladder Program, developed by graduate students, for graduate students, serves as a nimble and cost-effective national model for PhD career development and exploration. The traditional career pathway for PhD students in the sciences, leading to a faculty job, is no longer reliable. Numerous recent reports have called on universities to provide better career development and preparation to help these highly-trained scientists and engineers go on to productive and satisfying careers in a broader range of job sectors. To create the necessary culture change and provide these resources, institutions need cost-effective, easily adaptable models that can transform from the bottom up. The PhD Career Ladder Program is a student-led career mentoring program that takes students through an eight-step curriculum of self-assessment, career exploration and preparation for a job search. Because the program is grassroots and peer-to-peer, it creates a supportive space for exploration of career paths inside and outside of academia and encourages persistence toward students' career goals. This National Science Foundation Research Traineeship (NRT) award in the Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) Track to Stony Brook University will focus on expanding, improving and institutionalizing the PhD Career Ladder Program, and testing its effectiveness as a career development tool.

This award will allow Stony Brook to expand the existing PhD Career Ladder Program (PCLP) to new cohorts and develop standardized training for new peer leaders. The success of PCLP will be assessed through evaluation of its impact on participants as well as the effectiveness of its programmatic elements. Key measures include increasing student career knowledge and skills, enhancing students' confidence in their career prospects, transferable skills and job-search skills, broadening students? career horizons to include the pursuit of careers beyond academia, and cultivating a pipeline of new student leaders. The assessment also will measure research-grounded psychosocial variables such as shifts in scientific identity and perceived identity compatibility with diverse career pathways. The program, including the new train-the-trainers component and the expansion of PCLP to new student cohorts, will be assessed formatively throughout the project as well as summatively at the end of the project. Finally, findings on this highly adaptable and cost-effective model will be disseminated broadly, through an online clearinghouse of archived material and a program implementation toolkit.

The NSF Research Traineeship (NRT) Program is designed to encourage the development and implementation of bold, new, potentially transformative models for STEM graduate education training. The Innovations in Graduate Education Track is dedicated solely to piloting, testing, and evaluating novel, innovative, and potentially transformative approaches to graduate education.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
Only a fraction of graduate students go on to become professors and yet most graduate training focuses on preparation for academic careers. In order for the scientific workforce to derive full benefit from graduate-trained scientists and innovators, universities need career exploration and development programs for their graduate students that prepare them to pursue the full spectrum of diverse career options.

The PhD Career Ladder Program, known as PCLP, is a cost-effective, easily adaptable model of graduate student-led career development that was originally created by doctoral students at Stony Brook University. This project, supported by the Innovations in Graduate Education program [Grant No. DGE-1735210], aimed to refine PCLP into a form that was easy to implement and institutionalize by any university while maintaining its core value in being student-led. The peer-to-peer nature of PCLP has long been its secret ingredient, with students regularly reporting that working through the seven career development steps together helped them feel "not alone" in their career concerns and hopes. The program's peer-to-peer support became even more important during the COVID pandemic, creating critical peer connection (as recommended for trauma-informed training by the CDC) among far flung participants once the program became virtual. 

Through rigorous pre/post assessment of 57 individual groups of 482 participants, led by 56 grad student and postdoc leaders, over six years, the project found every year that participants reported an increase in knowledge and preparation for pursuing diverse careers, an increase in the range of careers perceived as acceptable for someone with their training, and an increase in confidence and self-efficacy in pursuing careers. Of those who fully completed the program, just over half have graduated with a master's or doctoral degree so far. Of those graduates for whom we could identify a first destination job, about half worked in academia, almost a third worked in the for-profit private sector, and the remaining were split between working for the government and for a non-profit. Overall, PCLP alumni are getting jobs related to their degrees across a diverse range of workforce sectors.

The final program curriculum consists of seven bi-weekly steps that roughly follow the format of an Individual Development Plan: (1) self-assessment and reflection, (2) career research, (3) informational interviews, (4) skill identification and strengthening, (5) CV and resume crafting, (6) networking, and (7) career planning and goal setting. The ideal characteristics for a successful program are: small group sizes (5-8) to ensure that participants all have time to report back and discuss their progress; student leadership for individual groups and in coordinating the peer leaders; and a diverse mix of disciplines within a group to allow for multi-dimensional feedback and sharing. In order to institutionalize the grassroots program, PCLP has become a 0-credit graduate course, GRD 510, where student peer leaders lead each section/group and the course director coordinates the group in collaboration with a student Leader Coordinator. The format has increased students' regular attendance by fostering accountability and providing a predictable schedule, while also providing transcript documentation of students' commitment to their career development. Housed centrally in the Stony Brook University Graduate School, the course is offered with multiple sections/groups every semester.

A key deliverable of this project is a toolkit for implementing the program at any institution. The toolkit includes step-by-step moderation guides, email and promotional outreach templates, and a career resource repository. The initial toolkit has been tested through adaptation at 10+ institutions serving master's students, doctoral students, and postdocs. The toolkit will be available for public download from the professional development clearinghouse pd|hub as part of their career exploration collection at https://www.pdhub.org/collections/career-exploration/series-peer/ starting in 2025 following two additional rounds of pilot testing at additional universities.  

 


Last Modified: 01/01/2024
Modified by: Kathleen Ehm
